fr:title.text: Canonical forms of matrices from fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Canonical forms of matrices from fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We should observe that if \mathbb {F} is a field, then \mathbb {F}[x] is a principal ideal domain. The idea is that if we have a linear operator L\colon M\to M where M is a finitely-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {F}, then M is a finitely-generated module over \mathbb {F}[x] where x acts on M as described by L.
Then the decomposition of M as a finitely-generated module over \mathbb {F}[x] into a direct sum of submodules gives us a decomposition of L into a block diagonal matrix.
Depending on which form of the fundamental theorem we use, we end up with two different decompositions of L into either the rational canonical form or the Jordan canonical form.
